concern:
For context, I (19m) am currently attending my local cc with plans to be a nursing major starting next fall. My plan is to either stay at my cc to get my ADN first or transfer directly to a university to get my BSN.

So anyway, this past few months I've been struggling somewhat with some self esteem issues and FOMO. We all know that going to a cc is very different from attending a 4 year university. I actually didn't know that until a few months ago and as soon as I did I started panicking because I thought I was already having the "college experience" that people talk about.

I have not been to a single college party since starting at my cc or done any of the fun stuff people associate with college. I have a few friends at cc but not very many and the ones I do have I don't see very often because they're majoring in different things.

Additionally, I've struggled quite a bit with my self esteem mainly in terms of my body image. This isn't by any means new for me but I do think it's gotten worse over the past few months. I was using the gym at my cc for a little bit but I eventually came to the realization that I didn't have time to workout every day. I started studying way more and my grades have improved greatly but every day by the time I've finished all my work and/or studying I feel so drained that I can't bring myself to do anything more than lay on my bed and watch YouTube.

There are other things that I've struggled with in relation to my self esteem that probably sound pretty dumb like that I'm not "masculine" enough or things like that.

I'll admit that when all of this was at it's worst I wasn't exactly in the right mind. It was around the start of the semester and I was readjusting to taking my ADD meds again and I was very sleep deprived. It is significantly better now but it's still not great and I would like to hear about other people's experiences.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! I'm here to listen and support you. What's on your mind today?

I've been struggling with some selfesteem issues and feelings of missing out on the typical college experience. It's been affecting my daily routine, and I'm hoping to work through it with your support.

It sounds like you're going through a tough time right now, feeling like you're missing out on something important. That can be really hard to deal with, and it's great that you're reaching out for support. Can you tell me more about what's been happening?

I've been feeling a lot of pressure from comparing my community college experience to the typical university social scene, which has worsened my selfesteem. It's made it tough to stay motivated with daily routines like studying and selfcare.

It's understandable that comparing your experience to others can be tough on your selfesteem. It's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique, and there's no one right way to do things. It's great that you're aware of how this is impacting your daily routines. Have you tried any strategies to manage these feelings?

I've tried exercising at the gym to boost my selfesteem, but it became too hard to maintain with my study schedule. Recently, I've been focusing more on my studies to improve my grades, which helps a bit with my overall motivation but leaves me feeling exhausted.

It's great that you've been taking steps to improve your selfesteem and motivation, even if it hasn't always been easy. Balancing school and selfcare can be a tough challenge, and it's totally normal to feel exhausted at times. How do you feel about trying to find a balance between studying and selfcare that works better for you?

I think finding a better balance between studying and selfcare sounds helpful, even if I'm worried about how to fit it in without falling behind. I'm open to trying new strategies, as long as they don't add more stress to my already busy routine.

It's really positive that you're open to trying new strategies. Maybe we can explore ways to incorporate selfcare into your routine without adding too much extra stress. For example, have you considered breaking selfcare activities into smaller, more manageable chunks throughout the day, rather than trying to fit in a full gym session?

I've considered breaking selfcare into smaller chunks, like short walks or quick stretches, but I haven't fully tried it yet due to my packed schedule. I'm open to exploring this approach if it could help ease my exhaustion and improve my overall selfesteem without overwhelming me.

Let's start by setting a realistic goal for this week. How about aiming to incorporate two short selfcare activities, like a 10minute walk or some stretches, into your daily routine? This way, we can test out this approach without adding too much extra stress. Does that sound doable?

Yes, that sounds doable for me, as short activities like a 10minute walk could fit into my routine without adding much stress. I'm hopeful it might help ease my exhaustion and give a small boost to my selfesteem.

Awesome, I'm glad that feels manageable. Remember, it's not about perfection, but about finding a balance that works for you. You've got this!  Let's check in next week to see how it's going and adjust as needed.

Thanks for the encouragement I'm feeling motivated to try these small selfcare activities and see if they help ease my selfesteem struggles. I'll definitely check in next week to update you on how it's going.

dialogue_conv:
